reviewText: .  .  . but, I also find this attempt at 'Mahler in a capsule' a bit flawed in terms of biography, as well as in regards to dealing with Mahler's music. Let me say right off, disc 1 is FAR better than disc 2.In disc one, we get a thorough visit in and around Mahler's hometown, which was referred to as Iglau in Mahler's time (it now has a Czech name). This brings us to one important detail that Tilson Thomas chose not to emphasize, which is that Iglau was very much a German speaking town. Located near the border between Bohemia and Moravia, it's believed that few people spoke Czech there, and that Iglau's Jewish population was less than 10%. This matters only in that it needs to be made clear that Mahler grew up in a home and region which had German speaking, Austrian ambitions. While a bit of a brute, Mahler's father read quite a bit of German literature and kept a modest library. This might have been the only characteristic that Mahler picked up from his father, as Mahler was an avid reader of German Lit. as well. In fact, Mahler's literary and poetic knowledge was very much an influence upon his musical compositions. Hugely so.Where Tilson Thomas truly excels is in his ability to take the sounds and sights of Mahler's hometown and surrounding countryside, and relate that to what happens in Mahler's precocious first symphony. The military bands (Iglau was a garrison town of the Hapsburg Empire), the organ grinders, the local tavern musicians, the sounds of nature from the surrounding region - all this gets thrown into Mahler's kaleidoscopic brand of symphonic writing. Tilson Thomas does a superb job of putting all this together. One interpretive touch on MTT's part, is that he relates the ending brass chorale in the finale (actually, it makes two big appearances in the finale) to the "Hallelujah Chorus" from Handel's "Messiah". As a result, when we look at the complete performance, MTT takes that brass chorale at a slower, more majestic tempo than usual. I'm not convinced of that, but neither is it offensive. Still, disc one is pretty much a winner. Where I truly have problems is with the handling of the rest of Mahler's musical life on disc 2.First off, if we're to take Mahler's own words at face value, he considered his colossal 8th symphony to have been his greatest. As I recall, the 8th doesn't get touched upon at all (if it does, it's barely so). Only the weird and macabre get emphasized from Mahler's 7th symphony (the middle movement) - a symphony which is not only another one of Mahler's 'darkness-to-light' traversals, it could also easily be described as Mahler's 'concerto for orchestra'. My point is this: what about the gorgeous and other-wordly middle section from the long first movement, or the hybrid nocturne/Italian serenade that is the second Nachtmusik (the erudite fourth movement)? That's to say nothing of the wild and kaleidoscopic mumbo-jumbo of Mahler's raucous finale. Obviously, no quick musical biography can do justice to all of Mahler's incredible output. But the middle period symphonies are so intense, and so much of what Mahler was building up to throughout his career, that the whole program fails to educate anybody on what Mahler was really all about. Even the 'tragic' A-minor 6th symphony hardly gets touched upon - just the usual nonsense of emphasizing Mahler's novelty act: the hammer strokes (they're to be non-metallic in sound). Was the A-minor simply a loud and tedious essay on Mahler's insecurities and personal problems, or was it a tragedy in the classic Greek sense of the word - cathartic in nature, that is? Or, could it be that Mahler, along with many of the other intellectuals and artists of his day, visualized disaster and end of the old European monarchies, along with the time-honored, European ways of dealing with political strife that accompanied those monarchies?None of this gets discussed at all. Instead, we're fed the usual, 'why would Mahler write a tragic symphony at the height of his powers?' routine. The real question is this: who cares WHEN Mahler chose to write his tragic A-minor symphony? From a purely musical standpoint, it could be that the darkness-to-light fifth symphony was a 'proben' (rehearsal) for the coming sixth symphony - an exercise in counterpoint and massive brass sonorities. We just don't know. But emphasizing Mahler's early and late period works at the expense of the intense central period works is not unlike the experiences of those who have studied music at conservatories, only to suffer their professors emphasizing early and modern music at the expense of all the music in the middle - the music of which the vast majority of listeners care about. We care about ALL of Mahler's music, which is why skimming over the middle is such nonsense.The best solution, in my opinion, would have been to make this a three-disc program; a disc each for the early, middle and late (farewell trilogy) works. This would have benefited our knowledge of Mahler's output in other ways, such as matching up the symphonies of each period with their corresponding song cycles: "Des Knaben Wunderhorn" (not touched upon at all) and "Songs of a Wayfarer" (thoroughly covered) for symphonies 1-4; "Kindertotenlieder" and the "Five Ruckert Songs" for symphonies 5-8. Then it could have been pointed out the 8th symphony - the Beethoven's 9th of the Art Nouveau era - is a hybrid of Oratorio and symphonic forms, while Mahler's very next work, "Das Lied von der Erde", takes the next step by morphing a cycle of songs into a full blown symphony. Then we would really learn something about Mahler's music, and what it was that he was trying to do with it.All this then segues into the troubled question of Mahler's unfinished 10th symphony. As is often times the case, Tilson Thomas chose to look at just the Adagio first movement. He's not alone, so he's not wrong. But there's a catch: Mahler also completed the short and very different "Purgatorio" movement (third movement out of five). This is what led Deryck Cooke to be suspicious in the first place. After studying the rest of the manuscripts, it became apparent to Cooke that Mahler was very much attempting to move on with his life - both biographically and musically. In other words, the 10th isn't - as Leonard Bernstein rather blindly stated - yet another attempt to simply say farewell. Again, none of this mentioned.In the final analysis, there's little point in harping on the 'should-a/could-a's of this beautifully produced and packaged program. As handsomely as the various locations were captured in that "Rick Steve's Europe" kind of way, a more even handed discussion and look at Mahler's complete oeuvre would have been welcomed. Get this as a Mahlerian travelogue and detailed look at the first symphony.
summary: this is what MTT is so great at, and it's a very glitzy presentation, but  .  .
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would never claim to understand the bulk of Gustav Mahler's Works, or Life = there is way too much Volume & exceptionally high degree of achievement there, with incredible density and Quality of output during his relatively brief Lifetime of only 50 years (brief by our modern standards).Mahler seems like the Ultimate `Overachiever' becoming the Top Conductor of his Day (in both Symphonic Music and especially Opera) - meticulously memorizing hundreds of Classic Scores => then tirelessly `working' himself, and his Orchestras to perform far above normal expectations, and beyond any traditional Limits ==> extracting and generating mind-blowingly unprecedented Concert performances, mainly to the waiting ears of hyper-critical Viennese audiences from a little over 100 Years ago (of course these descriptions are based on selective readings of historical commentary - since no high quality recordings exist, of the actual performances - but there is more than ample `documentation' to support their validity).Mahler would have secured his significant place in Musical history, had he only been known for the unprecedented impeccable & deeply inspired Conducting!But his incredibly complex original Symphonic Works - in which he literally tried to Capture & encapsulate our Entire living World - are almost beyond description (at least beyond my own limited ability to do so).That's where Michael Tilson Thomas (aka MTT) and this exemplary Documentary on the Life and Works of Gustav Mahler come into play!MTT definitely has both the credibility and considerable experience to lead the viewer (and listener) through this somewhat daunting & potentially intimidating subject matter* having conducted a `full cycle' of Mahler's Works to significant acclaim, with the San Francisco Symphony!Of course MTT has already done a number of these invaluable `Keeping Score' documentaries, I haven't seen them all - but was especially impressed with the ones on Tchaikovsky's #4, and Beethoven's Great Watershed `Eroica' Symphony 3!In this Mahler documentary, MTT seems to take special care to have the viewer `enter into' Mahler's actual `surroundings' and give us a taste of what it might have been like to actually grow-up in this culturally cosmopolitan environment, near the heart of the Austro-Hungarian empire, in the Late 19th Century (with all the diverse musical `influences' Mahler would have been exposed to there!)MTT then roughly traces-out Mahler's professional Life/achievements => progressing thru the Larger and better Opera Houses throughout Europe, and beginning to make a name for himself as an exceptional and inspiring Conductor!Then to Mahler's initial forays into composing highly original Works of his own (and the burgeoning confidence that one day, his Time would come => when audiences could begin to understand and appreciate these innovative & complex Symphonies = Some say it took the devastation and ensuing Chaos of WWII and aftermath, for audiences to finally realize the prescient insights inherent to some of these very 'tumultuous' Works.)Then on to his significantly impactful courtship with the somewhat eternally unattainable (but still one-great-Love) `Alma'!Then an actual visit to his Summer `composer's cottage' (imbued with the paradoxical combination of both early magical/optimism  & then Later forlorn/ heartbreaking Loss).On to his Later Masterful Works => then brief but significant time in America ==> then back to Europe and come-too-soon Death.This is Essential viewing for any Mahler fan, or anyone just fascinated by Music composition and its historical development - Mahler representing a kind of a valedictory Culmination, just prior to its impending `deconstruction' by Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Webern, etc.Huge gratitude to MTT and this invaluable documentary series = a very worthy successor to those Legendary Leonard Bernstein educational `talks' and musical expositions, like the Great `Unanswered Question' DVD series!Note*:  I was very much intimidated and even a bit wary of Mahler's compositions at first, because they are Gigantic and seem to be so intent on Capturing such a great volume of subject matter/ incredible density (ie. packed to the rafters, until almost ready to burst!) and are also incredibly Long!  I am still intimidated by a number of them (like the 6th, 8th, and 3rd) - but have grown quite `attached' to the 5th, 7th, 2nd and 1st (go figure!)  -  the 9th I am still processing  (this might take awhile - perhaps even a Lifetime!)
summary: Essential DVD = in the Long Winding Road to Understanding Gustav Mahler and his Works - with MTT as exceptional Guide!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wasn't sure what I could add to the 11 other reviews but after reading them, I want to note the following -- the production values are amazing.  The location work including reconstructions of potential events in Mahler's home village are impressive.  The Blu Ray images are clear as is the sound.  This is a program about Mahler's life and not a detailed exploration of all of his symphonies.  I can fully understand the need to be selective in creating a TV program.  Those looking for a detailed exploration of each symphony will be disappointed.  Like many other Blu Ray disks this one does not remember where it was when "stop" is pressed or the player is turned off.  Each time one takes a break the program will start from the beginning unless "pause" is used.  This is a problem with the DVD authoring and not a defect in the blu ray specifications.  It seems stupid to have such a technilogical marvel as a blu ray disk and have to write down on paper the chapter whenever one stops.
summary: Probably the best in the Keepin Score Series
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Francis G. Lu "Emeritus Luke & Grace Kim Endo...
reviewText: This double Blu-ray disc edition is a beautiful story of Mahler's life and music. It features many actual locations of his life from his hometown to his grave, both as seen today and in archival footage. In between, we have excerpts from his music expertly played by the SF Symphony and wonderfully explicated by Music Director Michael Tilson Thomas. Disc two is a playing of the First Symphony. Audio and video are both stunning. I had the same problem as the first reviewer when the disc froze up when playing it on anOPPO BDP-83 Blu-ray Disc Player with SACD, DVD-Audio, and VRS Technology, but it was resolved with a firmware upgrade from the Oppo website.
summary: Great story of Mahler's life and music
Title: N/A

reviewText: Prequel: To address the issue as to whether the Blu-ray discs play or not.This Blu-ray disc, recorded in 2009 and issued in 2011, seems to have caused a few problems in playback. Although clearly labelled as 'Region 1' (why not 'A'?), it seems to be multi-region as my Region B Marantz UD 7007 plays it perfectly (but my slightly older Marantz 7006 freezes as described by others having loaded up OK). This seems to be a problem of uploading the latest software therefore...................Now for the contents:The documentary is a double length feature of nearly two hours. The first part deals mostly with the background to the first symphony plus illustrated examples of all the main points to do with the actual music. The second part takes us through the remainder of Mahler's life with musical extracts from symphonies 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, Song of the Earth and 10 as well as extracts from his song cycles. We are also taken on a tour of his work places and a full description is given of his 'life's journey.' This extensive double documentary is extensive and utterly of interest offering many insights even for those who have depth of knowledge of this complex composer and character. It makes compulsive viewing for everyone and is invaluable for those coming fairly new to Mahler. Michael Tilson Thomas's presentation and enthusiasm is completely engaging as in the rest of this fine series.The performance of the symphony boasts the finest recorded sound of this work that I have ever heard. Played back on good quality audio equipment of wide range it is simply extraordinary. The visual imaging is of the same standard being clear, detailed but not invasive. It is not hyperactive either which is a blessing!As an interpretation the performance is very upbeat in character with little of the 'angst' to be experienced in the later works. Essentially this is an optimistic work seen as a whole and, as such, it is given an optimistic reading of considerable corporate and individual virtuosity. The darker and quieter moments are fully explored and there are many passages of considerable beauty to be experienced but the darker aspects do not dominate this performance. Tilson Thomas' committed enthusiasm and communication with all the members of his very fine orchestra is unmissable and infectious.In summary I would suggest that this is a particularly fine issue in a remarkably fine and engaging series of recordings. As such it deserves the most serious consideration as a potential purchase.
summary: 'Region 1' Blu-ray plays well on 'Region B' player - a terrific production

This was a gift for my "Little Brother" who plays the tuba and would like to attend Julliard when he reaches that stage in his young life.

reviewText: First, here's what you'll find in this set:1.  a full performance of Mahler's Symphony 1 by Michael Tilson Thomas (MTT) and the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra.2.  a roughly two-hour program on the life and music of Gustav Mahler.One disc is a full performance by MTT and the SFSO of Mahler's first symphony.  Michael precedes it with a brief but helpful introduction that prepares the audience for the symphony.  It's a good performance, with the first movement leading up to the "cuckoo theme" done much more softly than is common.MTT obviously enjoys conducting Mahler's music, frequently looking like a child, delightfully surprised at each new phrase (even though he knows exactly what's coming!)  We should all bring such a childlike delight to the magical music of Mahler.The other disc:How can the life of one of the world's greatest composers and conductors be told in about two hours?  You're right--it isn't easy, but Michael Tilson Thomas (MTT) succeeds better than any before him.  He tells the story of Mahler's life and music, with musical excerpts accompanying scenes of places where Mahler lived.  The view of the open fields of Kaliste, where Mahler was born, serves as a point of reference to the spaciousness of some of his music.  There are also great views of Iglau (today called Jihlava)--it's much larger than most of us would imagine, and most of it is just as it was in Mahler's time.MTT takes us on a video trip along the streets that served as milestones or important features in Mahler's childhood:  the forest, his father's tavern, the synagogue where Mahler, the small child, interrupted the cantors shouting, "Be quiet, be quiet.  It's horrible!"  The small child then sang his favorite song, the "Knapsack Polka" to show them how music SHOULD sound.Next, we get a movement-by-movement "tour" of Symphony 1, followed by well-chosen scenes from Mahler's world at the time of each symphony.  I should add that many scenes are moving videos rather than just the usual still photos.A good point that MTT remembers to include is the wonderfully beneficial affect that conducting so many operas--especially those of Wagner--had on Mahler's music.  His desire to make each opera as attractive as possible to the audience and to "paint" scenes or motives such as Wagner had done, helped develop his gigantic abilities as a composer and orchestrator.  A composer with his ear tied only to a piano, sometimes is less aware of the palette that a conductor has at his disposal.There are good views of each of Mahler's "composing huts" and even a rare opportunity to see the inside of Mahler's Vienna Court Opera summer chalet on the south side of Lake Werther--still just as it was when Mahler walked the halls and enjoyed with friends the view from his veranda balcony.  In his "cottage of solitude," Mahler attempted to elude the curious tourists that tried to get a glimpse of the famous conductor.  Many of them were "Kur Gaste" (Cure Guests) people at the lake for a spa-like cure for their ailments.  Mahler called them "Kuh Gaste" (Cow Guests) for their piggish manners and rude behavior.I was glad to see that MTT illustrates very nicely, the use of unusual instruments--something so typical of Mahler:  cowbells, sleighbells, the rute (a band of sticks), a deliberately mis-tuned violin (for a rustic effect) and the seventh symphony's use of a snapped string pizzicato where basses become a new percussion instrument.There are so many other things to mention, but I was delighted to see MTT address a topic many seem to fear to approach:  that Mahler's music often brings tears to the eyes of Mahlerians.  They are not only tears of sadness, but also tears at the supreme and fragile beauty that Mahler has constructed in his music.  Soprano Susan Graham tells MTT that we cry because, "it wakes up feelings and emotions inside ourselves."  MTT adds, "Beauty makes us cry because we fear it can't last.  Mahler teaches us to cherish the wonder of each moment."In a very few, carefully-chosen words, MTT summed up Mahler's often wayward wife, Alma, by saying she "presented herself as a kind of aesthetic pin-up girl."  Those who have read Almas diaries or biographies of Alma and Gustav will see the aptness of this description.Finally, to wrap up this well-planned and carried out story of Mahler's life and music, MTT tells of visiting, in the 1970s, the cemetery where Mahler is buried.  He remembered how, despite what an influence Mahler has had upon his own life, and the world of music, many people in Mahler's homeland still failed to see his importance.  He takes us to Mahler's simple grave--far away from the "important composers" such as Beethoven and Schubert.  Mahler had said, "Those who love me will know where to find me; for everyone else, it makes no difference."  As MTT places three red roses on Mahler's grave, he adds:  "To a lot of us, it makes a big difference!"  I was not entirely surprised to find tears of empathy sliding down my cheek.
summary: To a lot of us, it makes a big difference!

reviewText: I frequently watch documentaries about music of all genres, and I can say that this is one of the best I have ever seen (and heard).Michael Tilson Thomas has an obvious passion for Mahler's music, and his excitement is felt by the viewer, but what impressed me most was that even though you get the traditional chronological survey of Mahler's life and career, at appopriate times they juxtopose music from varoious periods to really give the "big picture" and show how everything is related. One great example was at the end of the program when they show how a theme from the beginning of Mahler's first song keeps returning, including at the end of the his final symphony. There is also a survey of the unique features of the scherzo movements iof many ot the symphonies, and these are shown in sequence. Also, as another reviewer mentioned, it is great to be shown all the unusual instruments that Mahler had used, including a demo of the hammer blows from the Sixth Symphony.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thomas does a superb job taking us on a visual tour of the sights/sounds of Mahler's youth.  And the performance of the first symphony shows off all of the conductor's insights splendidly.  Compared to (for example) Dudamel's rather literal reading, Thomas illuminates a myriad of rhythmic/melodic details that define the soul of this piece.  The string sound may lack the splendor of Vienna, but the woodwinds and horns are the glory here.  All the soloists shine as vivid characters in Mahler's "sonic goulash."  Indeed "character" might be the right word to use here.  This is a PERFORMANCE in the best sense of the word.  Never flashy,  rarely even loud, but as Isaac Bashevis Singer once said about Yiddish, it has more VITAMINS!One Kvetsch:  who was the schnorer who forgot to put the subtitles on "Songs of the Wayfarer?"  That's actually the only place on the whole package where they're actually essential!
Title: N/A
